comments.commentBody: Hi, I'm a friend of Martin Ashwood-Smith, who asked me to pass on the following:  "Try the easy clued version of today's puzzle (at the above link in the constructor's notes). It should show you that not all quadstacked puzzles are filled with hard fill and so-called "Naticks": two hard words crossing leaving an impossible to get square. If this were the case, an easy-clued version would be impossible."
They don't use ink jars, but fountain pens are still required in Germany (or at least were when I was a kid).

This fine article illustrates well the contingencies of history.  Many documents or other artifacts of history survive because of such unpredictable actions as that of Tad Lincoln.  On the other hand, we have lost crucial pieces of our past because of random disasters (fires, etc.) or because nobody at the time understood their value.  The fate of Lincoln's last speech also raises the question of whether such documents belong in private hands.  American history is the story that helps bind us together as a nation, and the artifacts of that history belong on public display, so that scholars and the average citizen have access to them.

I'm not a big Hilary fan and was not a big Bill fan.  I agree with commenters who cite elitism as their main concern.  Unfortunately, the USA is all about elites and has been since the Founding Fathers, most of whom were also elites.  So the choice is really between that candidate who hurts the little person the least.  The true leader sells out his (or her in this case) elitist friends and financiers to promote the common good.  I doubt Hilary will do this.  However, I am reasonably certain that none of the Republican candidates will.

Foundations don't work that way. Once money goes there, it's not the property of the donors and the Clintons didn't get salaries (or other compensation and that's public information contained in the foundation's tax returns). The foundation (s) existed before she was Secretary of State. Bill Clinton started his right after he was out of office.

It's not unreasonable to ask questions about undue influence, but why would they need to form a foundation to fund projects all over the world (which it does, with all its reporting requirements), if they could just peddle influence as well-connected citizens? The answer is that they don't need a foundation to earn money.

Anyone who knows how to research can find out who donated, where the money went and for what; it's public information (and easy to access) and so far I haven't seen the Obama Administration have any issue with any alleged untoward behavior--if it did, wouldn't that have already come to light?

I want to hear concrete examples of favorable treatment, to anyone who gave to the foundation, by the State Department under Clinton's leadership instead of baseless speculation, but I am not hearing it. Just implying it doesn't make it so.
I don't wear hats.  In any case, why review my review of the (non-)review if you don't think it's worth reviewing?

Let us add this: George H.W. Bush served in the military during WWII, Bill Clinton reneged on his word to serve by using his best trait" manipulation of people...

And by the way and economist worth their weight in salt will explain that the health of an economy during a presidents term is usually the result of their predecessor's policies and take some times years to see the results . As Reagan inherited Carter's mess and slowly fixed those problems, Bush inherited an economy starting to stabilize, which took to full fruition into the Clinton years.... But Clinton's policies began to erode the surplus Bush inherited as well as Osama still on the loose... Now even though when Obama took office the economy was at an historic low point, it really wasn't Obama's policies that started to slightly improve the economy during his 2 terms, but the result of Bush's....

Another point is that at least the Bushes at some point in their lives worked for a living, where as the Clinton's only have held government positions.. living off the tax payers...

I am aghast that people are still blaming Ralph Nader for the 2000 election fiasco.

It's never the fault of the registered Democrats and Gore supporters in Florida who decided not to vote in that election.

It's never the fault of Al Gore and the Democratic Party for running a worse campaign than Bush.

Nope, 15 years later and we're still scapegoating one man for that entire election. Democrats like to pride themselves for being the more "logical" and "educated" party, but all rationality gets thrown out the window when it comes to that particular event.

Therefore we should eliminate corporate taxes (which are really taxes on poor consumers) so these companies will bring their manufacturing and their jobs back to these shores.  No other civilized country taxes corporations.

As a long-term second generation shareholder of GE, I welcome this change. Since GE's concentration on the financial industry -- and that was long before the '08 crisis -- the company's value tanked for ordinary shareholders such as me. Until the mid-90s, every few years the stock doubled in value every, would split 2:1, and would increase the dividend. Then everything TPTB did ended up wrong for the company, as evidenced by its share price and low dividend. Don't forget that GE took its capital off-shore to avoid paying taxes. Can the business professors and their graduates, the Midget Brained Asses, give us a satisfactory explanation?
This just isn't true; lots of us dyed-in-the-wool liberal lefties don't like her one bit.

Since we haven't heard her policy positions yet, how would we know? Can anyone please everyone all the time? She once famously said that she's like a Rorschach test and people are constantly projecting what they believe and your perception doesn't match what she's said and done, when she's had the opportunity. I believe in the facts, not speculation. It's easy to find out what she did in the Senate and what her policy positions were in 2008, when she was running for President.

http://www.ontheissues.org/celeb/hillary_clinton_environment.htm

Correction: There was no "magic" in her successful 2000 run for the Senate in New York.  Mrs Clinton stumbled backwards to victory when Senator Moynihan retired and no formidable candidates challenged.  Her "listening tour" made native New Yorkers wince (and not in a good way).
@Johansson: You must be a huge fan if you've actually seen all of those movies.  Most of them didn't run more than a week or two here in the U.S. and some aren't even readily available on DVD.

Christine, I would so love to believe that Hillary has that "fire in her belly" and a personal belief that she would make the best leader of  America as you say you do believe.  I just dont.  I was so turned off by her tactics when running against Mr. Obama and see her more as shrewd than idealistic.  Shrewd is good!  But its not the best and pretty far from ideal. Nonetheless, Hillary is a strong LEADER and while her judgement may be iffy under pressure, her experience should serve her well in office, though less so on the campaign trail.  In her favor I think its gutsy for a major candidate who doesnt need to, to come out now when there is so much time for close inspection of her beliefs, background, controversy etc. If the election were held today, I would vote for Hillary, but as is the date and her entering the race, its way preliminary.

The Republicans must be trembling with delight at the prospect of having Hillary Clinton as the Democratic nominee. I don't think she'll get the nomination; too much baggage. Too much Bill. Too much money. The Clintons are plutocrats now and there won't be a dime's worth of difference between Hillary or (fill in the blank) the eventual Republican nominee. If she is the nominee the White House is hers to lose. And unfortunately this nation still has not recovered from George W. Bush. He nearly bankrupted us and his wars continue. We cannot afford Hillary. Nor can we afford whoever the Republicans choose. I'm a life-long Democrat and if it comes down to Jeb Bush versus Hillary I will grit my teeth in disgust and pull the lever for Bush. This is a depressing prospect.
If he had a very rich VP running mate could he make an indie run out of it with a self funded campaign ?
The only entity truly too big to fail is the federal government.

Not that there is any doubt, but NYC taxpayers should be clear that any administration that even THINKS of giving these types of guarantees will be removed form office immediately. Period.

Again, not that there was any possibility of such nonsense.

The only "baggage" is that manufactured by Republican operatives and repeated by Fox News.

The Clintons are the most investigated couple in America, with a Special Prosecutor spending $70 million in tax payer dollars, and he found exactly nothing but an extramarital affair conveniently recorded by a Republican operative Linda Tripp.

Sorry, they lambast what they fear - the next US President.

Boo hoo hoo. Someone who has made hundreds of thousands of dollars leveraging a government managed oligopoly complains when that oligopoly is threatened? Please. If Mr. Friedman's income was based on true market demand Uber would be no threat at all. The fact that Uber is a threat is an admission that Mr. Friedman was reaping ologopolistic returns. Game changing applications are based on two factors:
1) technological advances that make delivery of service easier and/or cheaper, and
2) breaking down barriers to entry, allowing more competitors at lower prices

The whole taxi medallion business is just begging for disruption.

Jimmy Buffet has a verse to a song that states ,
" it takes money to buy your freedom ", and many will agree to that.
There is a another school of thought that drives those that subscribe past the point of comfort and ability to experience the planet and life to believe not just in the intrinsic need and use of money but in the power and control of money. Sadly, I feel there is too often a debilitating link in the relationship.
All must choose their own beliefs and path.

A. Stanton -- "You are obviously dreading what you fully expect is coming next, the total collapse of the Iran deal."

Dream on. Netanyahu is completely isolated now that even the Saudis have accepted the deal. He and his hired chorus in Congress are holding out alone against the world and the polls in America.

"NOBODY else behaves the way North Korea behaves."

When it comes to creating a nuclear deterrent of their own, the South Koreans might be wise to act more like the North Koreans, rather than depending on a major power to risk nuclear reprisal in their defense. The Israelis at least were that smart. The South Koreans have the know-how and the means. I remain mystified as to why they have not acted before now.

Excellent and informative post that I think does a great job of putting things in perspective. And let's not forgive Bush's moronic "Axis of Evil" speech, or his invasion of Iraq, or the neocon's scary and ludicrous talk of an "American Empire." Can the states so designated by Bush be blamed for fearing that the immense power of the United States military would be turned there way? For a small, threatened state, nuclear weapons offer the only realistic defense against a bellicose superpower.

It will be many, many years before we undo the damage done by Bush and the neocons.

The Bush Admin did not want that deal with North Korea. The people in W's Admin and W's supporters opposed the deal when Clinton did it.

They took the first opportunity to kill the deal. That was the outcome they wanted.

This seems to blame it on N. Korean "cheating." That isn't the real story. A dispute can be resolved many ways. North Korea had been hard heads since the Korean War talks. Nobody could have been surprised by some confrontation. The point is that W took the very first opportunity to walk away from diplomacy and try sanctions and pressure to be tough. It didn't work.

Iran has never been the sort of hard heads the North Koreans have always been. It is cultural. We ought to realize the differences in two very different places and cultures.

There is no reason to think that Iran will behave in the same way as North Korea behaved. NOBODY else behaves the way North Korea behaves.

There is no reason to point at North Korea and presume that Iran will behave the same way. North Korea is nuts, they deliberately play nuts like Kissinger said of Nixon's desire to be unpredictable and scary.

Iran has never done that. It is just foolish to assume they will do it now.
age is not a problem. the problem is the other number: the number of candidates.
Steve -- In 1961, when Brian Epstein met the Beatles, John Lennon was 21 and Brian Epstein was 28. This is hardly pedophile territory.

Possibly relevant is that Brian Epstein was a closeted gay man who lived during what was still an extremely homophobic period in the UK and the U.S., and the well-known fact that he had an unrequited passion for John Lennon. Losing the Beatles likely meant much more for him than just losing a job.

She needs to find a cadre of middle class, non experts, to use as an advisory panel, not a focus group.  Too many well intended policy decisions miss their mark at the critical moment.  She needs to know what the price of milk is and why some people who appear to be middle class on paper, can't afford a new car.
